Award.AwardTitle: International Research Experience for Students (IRES): Climate Change and Threatened Salmonid Fishes in Northern Mongolia
Award.AbstractNarration:
Understanding the impacts of climate change on aquatic ecosystems requires disentangling the web of direct and indirect climate effects from other anthropogenic changes. There are very few undisturbed lakes and rivers in the world in which this might be possible. The Lake Hovsgol - Eg River system is one of them. This project team will bring a small group of U.S. graduate and undergraduate students to Lake Hovsgol (the 17th largest lake in the world by volume) and the Eg River (Lake Hovsgol's only outflow) to conduct ecological research with a focus on effects of climate change on threatened salmonid fishes. Specific projects include: (1) using tagging and genetics to understand spawning site fidelity and population structure; (2) diet and stable isotope studies to characterize the current food web compared to historical conditions; (3) developing a novel non-invasive photo markrecapture technique for estimating growth of taimen; (4) bioenergetic studies of threatened salmonids to understand their physiological responses to warming; (5) developing water and nutrient budgets to understand the effects of changing inputs from tributary streams into Lake Hovsgol; and (6) a variety of limnological and fish community sampling to understand long-term change and inter-annual variability.

Students will be paired with a mentor from among the 13 U.S. project collaborators, most of whom have already conducted research in the Lake Hovsgol - Eg River ecosystem. Students' prepartion will include plans for sample processing, data analysis, and manuscript writing to be completed upon their return from the field. Two U.S. mentors (rotating) and a Mongolian mentor will accompany students and supervise the field research.

Broader Impacts of this project include: (1) improving the knowledge base for management of aquatic ecosystems and threatened fishes in Mongolia and in other high latitude temperate environments; (2) providing an international research experience early in the academic careers of the student participants and extending their professional networks by working with project collaborators (11 institutions in 10 states in addition to our Mongolian collaborator); (3) engaging students in independent research projects (the majority of which should be publishable on their own) that also contribute to the broader goal of understanding how salmonid fishes respond to climate change in an otherwise nearly undisturbed system.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Anticipating and adapting to the impacts of climate change is one of most important scientific and societal challenges of our time.  High latitude lakes and rivers appear to be among the more sensitive ecosystems to climate change; however the magnitude and, in many cases, even the direction of ecological change are difficult to predict. Our research used threatened salmonid fishes in the nearly pristine Lake Hovsgol – Eg River Ecosystem of Northern Mongolia as a focal point for a broader inquiry into the effects of climate change on high latitude lakes and rivers.  At the same time, we trained 14 graduate and undergraduate students in aquatic field ecology and help broaden their research perspectives.

We found that climate change is only one of several human impacts on this remote region.  Lake Hovsgol is a large, clear, mountain lake with low population density.  Most of its watershed is protected as part of a National Park.  Nevertheless, lack of a functional waste management system in the park has lead to high levels of microplastic pollution - small pieces of plastic from food wrappers, plastic bags, and beverage bottles.  Illegal gillnet fishing in the National Park also appears to be more widespread than we had believed with gillnet fragments found at every one of our sample sites on the lake shore.  These results highlight the fact that human impacts extend to even some of the most remote lakes and rivers in the world.

While Lake Hovsgol may not be a completely pristine environment, it is an excellent location to study the genetic and morphological diversification of fishes as they expand to fill the available niches in a new habitat.  Fish and most other macroscopic aquatic animals are believed to have died out in Lake Hovsgol during the last ice age and have only recolonized since the ice retreated approximately 10,000 -15,000 years ago.  Our research on Hovsgol grayling, an endangered fish species found nowhere else on earth, shows that this species has developed two body forms to take advantage of different habitats and food resources.  There is an open water form that is adapted to feed on small zooplankton.  It has larger eyes and more gill rakers to better strain plankton from the water.  A nearshore form of Hovsgol grayling focuses on aquatic insects and is more similar to the Arctic grayling from which this unique species evolved.  While their body shape and diets are distinct, genetic differences between the two forms of Hovsgol grayling are not yet apparent.

Chemical markers in fish muscle tissue called stable isotopes provide a broader look at diets than examining stomach contents alone.  Using stable isotopes, we examined year to year variability in the food web connections of Lake Hovsgol from samples that we collected during this project as well as previous collections from expeditions in 2006 and 2009.  We found that year to year variability is generally smaller than the variability between different locations within the lake.  Despite being large and geologically quite old, Lake Hovsgol has a very short food chain with considerable diet overlap between predators and their prey.  This may be characteristic of a younger food web in which many species have not yet developed diet specializations.  Alternatively, the low nutrient content of the water and thus low food availability may mean that fish are forced to become generalists, making use of a wider range of food items.
